intro: Apargia hirta, commonly known as the hairy false nettle, is a perennial herb native to eastern North America. It belongs to the Apiaceae family, which includes carrots and parsley, and is characterized by its finely divided, fern-like leaves. The plant produces small, greenish-white flowers arranged in umbels, typical of the family. It thrives in moist, wooded areas and is often found in shaded, rich soils. Apargia hirta is known for its hairy stems and leaves, which give it its common name.
